author: Mehboob Jeelani
text:
A day before the start of the budget session, the Congress in its “working committee” meeting on Monday decided to reach out to “other like-minded parties” to challenge the government in both Houses of Parliament.

Since the last winter session was whitewashed with the Opposition taking unrelenting positions over the issues of “intolerance,” the political crisis in Arunachal Pradesh and the outbreak of the National Herald controversy, this time the Congress has two more issues — the JNU row and the Jat agitation in Haryana — to pin down the BJP government with.

“The responsibility for creating an atmosphere conducive to the smooth functioning of Parliament is that of the government,” said Congress president Sonia Gandhi, while addressing the members of the working committee at 10 Janpath.

In the wake of the ongoing JNU row on which the BJP questioned the Congress vice-president Rahul Gandhi’s patriotism, Ms. Gandhi hit back at the government saying that it lacked the moral grounding to issue what she described “certificates of patriotism and nationalism to Congress and its leadership.” Ms. Gandhi said the BJP “never took part in the freedom movement” and “never showed any respect to the Father of the Nation.”
title: Combative Cong. to take on BJP in Parliament
